Learning-outcomes.item: Explain the reasons for using different formats to represent numerical data.
Explain how negative integers are stored in twos-complement representation.
Describe Boolean Operations, gates, and flip-flops.
Describe numeric data representation and number bases, and convert numbers between bases. Convert numerical data from one format to another.
Understand binary logic circuits and Boolean algebra. Prove properties using truth tables.
Discuss how fixed-length number representations affect accuracy and precision.
Describe the internal representation of nonnumeric data.
Design, implement, test, and debug simple programs for Lego Mindstorms robots.
Use of control structures for programs (selection, repetition).
Discuss the importance of algorithms in the problem-solving process.
Understand the difference between an algorithm and a computer program.
Identify the necessary properties of good algorithms.
Understand algorithms for repetition, selection, input/output, assignment, and modules.
Explain the organization of the classical von Neumann machine and its major functional units.
Explain how an instruction is executed in a classical von Neumann machine.
Explain the objectives and functions of modern operating systems.
Understand the fundamental ideas of selected operating system functions, such as memory management.
Explain basic file types and operations.
Understand terminology of directory trees.
Understand fundamental ideas of disk scheduling.
Explain the characteristics that distinguish the database approach from programming with data files.
Cite the basic goals, functions, and social impact of database systems.
Discuss the evolution of early networks and the Internet.
Understand the fundamentals of network protocols and the Domain Name System.
List the contributions of several pioneers in the computing field.
Identify significant continuing trends in the history of the computing field.
